thread.section_title: Massive wall of molluscs native to Ukraine block London water network – Metro
thread.title: Massive wall of molluscs native to Ukraine block London water network
thread.title_full: Massive wall of molluscs native to Ukraine block London water network

author: Jen
title: Massive wall of molluscs native to Ukraine block London water network
text:
They are native to Ukraine (Picture: Thames Water) You’ve heard about fatbergs, the great mounds of grease clogging sewers beneath our streets. 
But let us present another denizen of the deep to haunt you: this mollusc.
An infestation of zebra mussels has been discovered in a tunnel leading away from Walthamshow Reservoirs in London, clogging up the waterway.
Thames Water posted a photo of the disturbing blockage, asking: ‘Do you know what it is?’
Native to Ukraine, the zebra mussel is an invasive species that can cause serious problems.

Originally from the Black Sea, it came here on the hull of boats and now threatens the UK’s water network as it can rapidly spread and block up pipes.
Tesco to stop selling Heineken, Amstel, Sol and Tiger The wall of mussels in North London was discovered by an inspector, who snapped a photo while wading through the tunnel.
After the water company posted their cryptic tweet today, one man responded by suggesting it looked like ‘a crystalline form of alien life’.
Thames Water has experience dealing with zebra mussels, as they are an established problem in their network.
In 2011, they had to remove nearly 800 tonnes of them from the main water tunnel into Walthamstow water works, at a cost of around £250,000.
Zebra mussels They breed very quickly, with one one them potentially spawning 30,000 offspring in just one season. An adult mollusc can grow up to two inches long. They cling together in ‘reefs’, blocking up pipes. Their stripy shells give them their name They cannot be eaten.
